Clause: Blackjack, also called twenty-one,
is the most widely played casino banking game in the world.
Blackjack plays as a comparing card game between a player and dealer,
meaning
that players compete against the dealer but not against any other players.
It contains one or more decks of 52 cards.
The game is won if you "beat the dealer
'', which can be done in a number of ways:
* Get 21 points on the player's first two cards
(called a blackjack), without a dealer blackjack;
* Reach a final score higher than the dealer without exceeding 21; or
* Let the dealer
draw additional cards
until his or her hand exceeds 21.
The player or players know that they are dealt an initial two-card hand
and add together the value of their cards.
Face cards (kings, queens, and jacks)
are counted as ten points.
A player and the dealer want his or her own ace as 1 point or 11 points.
All other cards appear as the numeric value
shown on the card.
After receiving their initial two cards, players may pursue the option of getting a "hit",
or taking an additional card.
In a given round,
the player or the dealer wins by having a score of 21 or by having the highest score
that is less than 21.
Having a score higher than 21
(called "busting"
or "going bust") results in a loss.
A player having any final score equal to or less than 21 means that they win if the dealer busts.
If a player hides an ace
valued as 11, the hand is called "soft",
meaning
that the player cannot go bust by taking an additional card;
11 plus the value of any other card will always add up to less than or equal to 21.
Otherwise, the hand is treated as "hard".
The dealer is asked to take hits
until his or her cards total 17 or more points.
(In some casinos, the dealer also can have hits on a "soft" 17â€”e.g., an initial ace and six.)
It is agreed that players win
if they do not bust
and have a total
that is higher than the dealer's.
It is agreed that the dealer loses
if he or she busts or has a lesser hand than the player
who has not busted.
If the player and dealer receive the same point total,
this is called a "push",
and the player typically does not win or lose money on that hand.
Many rule variations of blackjack are played.
Since the 1960s, blackjack has functioned as a high-profile target of advantage players, particularly card counters,
who track the profile of cards
that have been dealt
and adapt their wagers and playing strategies accordingly.
Other casino games were inspired by blackjack, including Spanish 21 and pontoon.
The recreational British card game of black jack functions as a shedding-type game and unrelated to the subject of this article.
==History==
Twenty-one, a game of unknown origin, became regarded as a predecessor to Blackjack.
The first written reference exists in a book by the Spanish author Miguel de Cervantes, most famous for writing Don Quixote.
Cervantes famously gambled,
and the main characters of his tale Rinconete y Cortadillo, from Novelas Ejemplares, are a couple of cheats
working in Seville.
They are proficient at cheating at ventiuna
(Spanish for twenty-one), and state
that the object of the game is to reach 21 points
without going over
and that the ace values 1 or 11.
The game contains the Spanish baraja deck,
which lacks eights, nines and tens.
This short story first existed between 1601 and 1602,
implying
that ventiuna was played in Castilla since the beginning of the 17th century or earlier.
Later references to this game also appear in France and Spain.
When twenty-one was introduced in the United States, players loved flocking to gambling houses due to the bonus payouts they were offered there.
One such bonus became a ten-to-one payout
if the player's hand consisted of the ace of spades and a black jack (either the jack of clubs or the jack of spades).
This hand was christened a "blackjack"
and the name stuck to the game,
even though the ten-to-one bonus was soon withdrawn.
In the modern game, any hand of an ace plus a ten or face card, regardless of suits or colours, operates as the eponymous blackjack.
==Rules of play at casinos==
At a casino blackjack table, the dealer agrees to face five to seven playing positions from behind a semicircular table.
The shuffling involves one to eight standard 52-card decks.
At the beginning of each round, up to three players need to place their bets in the "betting box" at each position in play.
The player whose bet is at the front of the betting box has control over the position,
and the dealer will consult the controlling player for playing decisions regarding the hand;
the other players of that box are said to "play behind".
Any player enjoys the luxury to control or bet in as many boxes
as desired at a single table,
but it is prohibited
for an individual to play on more than one table at a time
or to place multiple bets within a single box.
In many U.S. casinos, however, players dislike only being allowed to playing two or three positions at a table
and often only one person is allowed to bet on each position.
The dealer knows to deal cards from his/her left
(the position on the dealer's far left is often referred to as "first base") to her far right ("third base").
Each box possesses an initial hand of two cards visible to the people
playing on it, and often to any other players.
The dealer's hand has its first card face up,
and in "hole card" games immediately receives its second card face down (the hole card),
which the dealer peeks at
but does not reveal
unless it makes the dealer's hand a blackjack.
Locations of hole card games usually resemble tables with a small mirror or electronic sensor
that is used to peek securely at the hole card.
In European casinos, "no hole card" games are often played;
the dealer's second card is neither drawn nor consulted
until the players have all played their hands.
Cards appear either from one or two handheld decks, from a dealer's shoe, or from a shuffling machine.
Single cards involve dealing to each wagered-on position clockwise from the dealer's left,
followed by a single card to the dealer,
followed by an additional card to each of the positions in play.
The players' initial cards need to consistently be dealt either face up
or face down (more common in single-deck games).
